A year of the women
Centennial of women's suffrage spurs look at local women of achievement
text: A year of the womenNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSA year of the womenCentennial of women's suffrage spurs look at local women of achievementKiernan Dunlopkdunlop@s-t.comNEW BEDFORD — Over a century ago lifelong Fairhaven resident Elizabeth Terry Delano added her voice to a national cause.The well-known local artist put pen to paper and sent a letter to the Fairhaven Star urging Congress to grant full suffrage to women.Delano wasn’t the only woman with SouthCoast ties to fight for women’s suffrage, and this year local women are recognizing what they and other SouthCoast women have accomplished before and in the 100 years since the 19th amendment was ratified in 1920.Organizations around New Bedford are celebrating the centennial of women’s suffrage, but they are also highlighting that work still has to be done for women’s rights and to make voting a universal right.The New Bedford Whaling Museum is commemorating the anniversary of women’s suffrage through its Lighting the Way Project, which works to highlight the historical impact of women from the region. “2020 is really significant because it is the 100th anniversary of ratifying the 19th amendment… and that’s incredibly important but it’s not the full story,” Catherine Saunders, project coordinator for Lighting the Way, said. “That was a long fight and it only made it so someone can’t be denied just because of their sex, but you can deny them from voting for other reasons.”States that required voters to own property or pass a literacy test or pay a poll tax kept some women and men from voting even after the 19th amendment was ratified on Aug. 18, 1920, particularly women of color and poor women.Lighting the Way is working to highlight the history of women in the region as well known as men’s history, through compiling their stories on a website and in an interactive app that allows you to tour the city and learn women’s stories at different historical landmarks.Events also celebrating the anniversary include IGNITE: A Youth Showcase of Art Inspired by Historic Women of the SouthCoast presented in partnership with the YWCA on March 12.Suffragists are among those historic women in the SouthCoast, according to Saunders, though only a few have been confirmed as suffragists.The reason for that could be that women’s history was not very well documented, Saunders said, and women who were active in politics were seen as quirky.“There were women in the SouthCoast, who may not have identified as suffragists, but who worked to secure rights and voting access for these women as well as for men who did not have it,” a statement announcing the Whaling Museum’s centennial celebrations said.Suffragists who have been identified include artists Elizabeth Terry Delano and Cecil Clary Davis, physician Dr. Marie Equi, and educator Elizabeth Piper Ensley.“It’s interesting that artists are the activists here,” Saunders said, “It’s partly because they were of a class that had the free time to be interested in and engaging in political activity.”“Cecil (Clary Davis) was another person who defied the typical expectation,” Saunders said, “She traveled a lot, she was very active in the women's movement, and she put off getting married for a long time because she didn’t just want to be in a subservient relationship.”Davis, who summered in Marion and won several awards for her art, was active in the suffrage movement from 1911-16, attending suffrage meetings and parades, and working on a suffrage cartoon and designing a poster for a suffrage parade, according to the Lighting the Way project’s website.Equi went from being a high school dropout working in the textile mills of New Bedford to graduating from the University of Oregon Medical Department and setting up her own practice in Portland.While in Oregon she joined the Oregon Equal Suffrage Association and fought for women’s reproductive rights and workers’ rights.“You completely see that that social justice leaning came from her experience in New Bedford,” Saunders said.Elizabeth Piper Ensley was an African American suffragist who was born in New Bedford and became active in the suffrage movement when she was a professor at Howard University, according to local historian Lee Blake.Ensley later worked with the National Association of Colored Women (NACW) in Colorado, helped women secure the right to vote in the state in 1894, and founded the Colored Women’s Republic Club to educate women of color on how to vote and why they should vote.Elizabeth Carter Brooks, the first African American woman to be hired as a public school teacher in New Bedford, was also active in organizing the vote for black people and black women, according to Blake.Women of color and white women didn’t necessarily work together in the suffrage movement.“The white suffragettes really did not want to be working with black women because they were so paranoid that if they accepted black women white Southerners would not work with them,” Blake said, “They did not want to antagonize the white Southern women.”According to Blake, there were African American women who were in the forefront of the fight, but were standing alone.Though women have come a long way in the last hundred years, there are still gains that need to be made, according to Saunders.“Part of what we need to gain is a sense of our own history,” Saunders said, “Our history has been hidden, not told, lost. So we’re reclaiming our history by compiling and putting out these stories of women so that people understand what women have contributed to our communities and what women are capable of.”In addition to the art exhibition, Lighting the Way is partnering with YWCA to present Lighting the Way to Equality on April 18, a discussion with historian and author Melanie Gustafson about women’s struggle for political inclusion.When asked why they wanted to participate, YWCA Director of Advocacy & Resource Development Jordan Pouliot Latham said, “Of course we would.”“We were always going to be talking about the anniversary of the 19th amendment and 2020 is such an important year with the census and the election,” Latham said.Latham is also the co-director of the Womxn’s Alliance, a group of over 40 organizations in New Bedford with the goal of creating a resource for women in the SouthCoast.The x in Womxn’s Alliance’s name is an intetional choice according to Latham, “The x in womxn is used to promote intersectionality, and to explicitly include femme, transgender women, and genderqueer and non-binary individuals.”“This (alliance) has been happening for a while now, but to see it all coming together is pretty remarkable,” Latham said. ”It’s led to some really amazing grant awards.”The Womxn’s Alliance has developed a calendar featuring dozens of events related to women and feminist issues, including events related to the centennial of suffrage.The events, Latham said, will acknowledge that not all women were able to vote as a result of the 19th amendment and that voter purges and voter disenfranchisement are still happening to this day.Forms of voter suppression today include strict government issued ID laws, bans on criminals charged with felonies voting, counties with larger minority populations having fewer polling sites and poll workers per voter, and only 40% of polling places fully accommodating people with disabilities, according to Latham and statistics from the ACLU.Latham said she hopes that these events will build a coalition that intersects class, race, generation, residence and more “to improve the lives of women and children in our community.”“In order to build a more inclusive and robust community ,we have to have solidarity , and we're only going to do that if we do it through an intersectional approach,” Latham said.The Women’s Fund, which is a member of the Womxn’s Alliance will also be commemorating the anniversary, according to Executive Director Joanne Murray.“We’re going to have our 20th anniversary symposium in the fall and a key topic will be the acknowledgment of the 100th anniversary of women’s suffrage and where we’ve come and where we still need to go,” Murray said.Women’s lives have improved tremendously in the last 100 years, women have a lot more choices and there have been significant breakthroughs in surviving childbirth; and women are now part of medical protocols.But women are not in enough positions of power, Murray said, for example far too few women are on corporate executive boards, only making up 1 to 2% of board members.Murray also noted, “Even though women have the same or slightly more levels of educational attainment as men, they don't have the same career progression as men.”One reason for that , according to Murray, is that we don’t have an effective child care system.When asked what obstacles women still face, Latham discussed the gender pay gap — especially as it breaks down by race and ethnicity, and women remaining largely underrepresented in political office .Murray wants young people to take up the mantle and continue the suffragists fight for women’s rights.“I think it’s really important that young people have been leading the environmental movement,” Murray said, “I hope they will not have a sense of complacency about continuing to fight for women’s rights.”That’s why projects like Lighting the Way are important, Murray said. It’s important to teach the historical significance of what these brave women did.The Zeiterion Performing Arts Center is also highlighting women’s story, offering a special promotion on women-centric performances in honor of March as National Women’s Month.“Women’s stories are ripe for the performing arts. They're beautiful, complex, painful, hopeful, resilient, powerful stories that are meant for stage,” Rosemary Gill, executive director of programming & development at the Zeiterion said, “As we see in our current climate, representation of women is still lacking in many areas. It is crucial for performing arts centers to showcase women and women’s stories to raise awareness not just about their lives, but about their significance — past, present and future.”Telling women’s stories acknowledges their contributions to society, according to Saunders.“I think the big idea that we want to make clear is whether or not women have had sanctioned power and authority, that women have made contributions and made a difference in multiple ways,” Saunders said. “And whether it's founding organizations that are key organizations in the community today, whether it’s organizing community members to be volunteers, whether it’s standing up and protesting conditions...women have claimed their own authority.”View in new tabCareers Accessibility Site Map Legals Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Terms of Service Privacy Policy Your Privacy Choices Staff DirectoryContact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Advertising Terms and Conditions Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give FeedbackSubscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X eNewspaper Archives InstagramJobs Cars Homes Classifieds Reviewed.com 10Best LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions© 2024 www.southcoasttoday.com.
